ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I'm not sure how useful it is for learning about science, but it was overall a fun experience and a good introduction to the department, and it wasn't very much work.
I will say it is a good guide for freshmen and will recommend it to other first-years.

I would describe as a very broadly applicable and highly variable lecture class with occasion discussion. I likely would not recommend the class to other students, but it is a requirement for the degree, so it is a must. If changes were made to realign the course's goals, I would TOTALLY recommend this class to others, but the class has somewhat waned from its original intent and description, in my opinion.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It gave me some broadening knowledge about EEB (as a subject in general, and also as a department). I think it made me better equipped to understand departmental seminars I have attended this semester and to talk to my classmates in other labs about their work. It didn't really contribute at all to my dissertation/research, but it probably made me a better colleague.
I think to me the course broaden my knowledge in EEB. I am not sure what this course will influence my disseration or research as I just begin...
I learned about myriad topics and resources I have to ask research questions within and tangentially to our department, which is super helpful.

This course helped broaden my idea of the types of research possible in biology and made me think more about interdisciplinary research. It also exposed me to the many resources available at Yale, which will be critical to my dissertation.

This course exposed me to the research of the faculty in our department, which is extremely helpful when considering lab rotations, collaborations, and faculty members as a source of knowledge and help when conducting our research.
